newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares steady early amid thin volume.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares steady early amid thin volume.

text.p: The Singapore stock market was firmer early Monday but in thin volume.
Dealers said rises were checked by jitters over Singapore's March non-oil domestic exports, scheduled for release at noon as well as by Sunday's bearish retail sales figures.
A poll of economists by Reuters last week called for domestic non-oil exports to decline 4.5 percent. Economists were uniformly negative with some suggesting a double digit fall.
The benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) was up 13.87 percent at 2,057.07, helped by institutional buying after the market recovered from striking 25-month lows last week.
"Trade is flat and volumes don't suggest anything except that people are sidelined," a local brokerage dealer said.
He added overall consensus was for domestic exports to post negative four to 10 percent for March.
Singapore markets were closed on Friday for a public holiday and some of the morning's momentum was attributed to a rise in the Dow on Friday and firmer Malaysian share prices.
Top gainers were Creative Technology, up Singapore 80 cents (US$0.56) to S$19.30 and SPH, up 30 cents to S$12.50 after posting a 9.2 percent half-year profit of S$172.38 million last Thursday.
